1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 29 (1985) 109 - 143 109 STRUCTURE OF THE ACTIVE LAYER AND CATALYTIC MECHANISM OF THE VzOs/MgO CATALYSTS IN THE OXIDATIVE DEHYDROGENATION OF ETHYLBENZENE TO STYRENE J. HANUZA Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, Department of Structural Chemistry, Wroctaw (Poland) B. JEZOWSKA-TRZEBIATOWSKA Institute of Chemistry, Wroctaw University, Wrocfaw (Poland) and W. OGANOWSKI Institute of Organic Chemistry, Department of Petrochemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Wroclaw (Poland) (Received January 5, 1984; accepted April 12, 1984) Summary A mechanism of oxidative dehydrogenation converting ethylbenzene to styrene on VzOg/MgO catalysts is suggested. The nature and structure of the V^/V^ active centres is discussed on the basis of the physicochemical (radio- graphic, thermogravimetric, electron microscopic, IR, RS, UV, VIS, ESR, luminescence and magnetic) properties. The V^V^/V111 redox system linked by oxygen bridges was shown to play an important role in the catalytic process. Introduction Metal oxides and oxy-compounds of vanadium and magnesium, and complex mixtures of both compounds, act as catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene [1 - 3]. It was decided to study these catalyst systems in order to elucidate the correlation between their structures, physicochemical properties and catalytic activities. The V20s/MgO catalysts employed by us made it possible to carry out the dehydrogenation with high degrees of conversion, selectivity and yields, most certainly due to the specificity of the surface layer structure of these catalysts. Such a generalization was possible after performing chemical, X-ray, thermogravi- metric, electron microscopic, IR, Raman, UV + VIS, ESR, luminescence and magnetic studies on the catalysts used. 0304-5102/85/$3.30 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 110 Experimental VzOg catalysts containing from 2 to 14% by weight vanadium were synthesized by impregnating MgO with aqueous ammonium metavanadate solution, drying at 120 C for 16 h and calcining at 600 C for 4 h. Catalysts were reduced in a flow reactor by means of gaseous ethylbenzene diluted with nitrogen. Studies were also prepared on catalyst samples containing 10% vanadium which were calcined at 600 - 800 C and then employed for 200 h under the reaction conditions. A full description of the syntheses and activity determinations are provided in a separate paper [4]. The reaction conditions were as follows: reaction temperature 520 C, contact time 0.04 s, molar ratio of ethylbenzene to oxygen 1:2, and atmospheric pressure. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography. Vanadium(V) content was determined manganometrically, whereas the concentration of vanadium at lower oxidation states was determined by the iodometric method. DTA measurements were carried out in a MOM derivatograph (Paulik- Paulik-Erdey system) over the temperature range 20 - 1000 C. These studies were carried out on the catalysts, mixtures of MgO and V^O^, corresponding to the stoichiometric composition of magnesium vanadates MgO^O; 1:1, 2:1, 3:1 and 3:2, and on the vanadates prepared by this method: MgV^Oo, Mg^O^andMgaV^O,. X-ray studies were carried out in a DR.ON-3 unit using Cu Ky radiation, X = 1.5418 A. Microphotographs were taken on a Tesia BS 500 transmission electron microscope. Infrared spectra, measured between 50 and 4000 cn-T1, were obtained by the KBr and polyethylene disk method in a Perkin-Elmer 180 spectrophotom- eter. The spectra were also measured by means of the reference beam compensation technique, in which the bands resulting from MgO were com- pensated. Raman scattering and luminescence spectra were measured in a DFS 24 spectrophotometer. The 4880 and 5145 A lines were used with an input power of 500 mW. The UV-VIS diffuse reflectance spectra were measured in Cary 14 and Hitachi spectrophotometers using MgO and MgC03 as reference samples. Measurements of the ESR spectra were performed in a JEOL-ME spectrom- eter using Mn^/MgO as a standard of the static magnetic field. Quantitative measurements of V4"1' contents and spin concentration were carried out by integrating the area under the absorption curve, which was determined by differentiating the ESR signal. Magnetic susceptibility studies over the 77 - 298 K range were carried out by the Gouy technique. An electronic Khan RH-2 microbalance and a magnetic field of 100 kGs were used. Ill Fig. 1. Thermogravimetric analyses of the vanadium-magnesium catalyst precursor and magnesium vanadate precursors; a) V;05/MgO catalyst precursor containing 10% vana- dium; b) 3MgO-2V20s;c) 2MgO-V20s;d) SMgO^Osie) MgO-V^Os; f) VzOg. 112 Results and discussion Chemical properties Figure 1 shows a comparison of the ATA curves obtained from thermo- gravimetric measurements of catalyst precursors and magnesium vanadates. Studies of the catalyst precursor revealed an exothermic effect at 615 C and endothermic effect at about 760 C. These effects correspond to the forma- tion and subsequent melting of the magnesium vanadate formed. Similar effects are also found in vanadate precursors. Apart from those described above, one can also observe a number of minor effects related to the decom- position of Mg(OH)2 and MgC03 formed temporarily on the catalyst surface and to the melting of V^O^. In general, it can be concluded from DTA measurements that during synthesis of the catalyst used later in the manufacture of styrene, a chemical compound magnesium vanadate is formed [5, 6]. Our studies do not confirm Speranskaya's [5] suggestion that the tetravanadate Mg3V40i3 is formed under the reaction conditions; according to our measurements, the ATA curve for that compound may be obtained by superimposing the curves describing the thermograms of MgV^O^ and Mg^V^O^. This conclusion is also confirmed by X-ray studies, which indicate clearly that Mg3V40i3 is an equimolar mixture of meta- and pyrovanadates. Because of a considerable dispersion and low V205 concentrations, X-ray studies of the catalysts with low vanadium contents did not lead to identification of the chemical compound being formed during synthesis of the catalyst. The reflections characteristic of magnesium orthovanadate became visible only for the catalyst containing 10% vanadium (Table 1, Fig. 2d). The orthovanadate phase appears in large quantities in catalyst samples containing more than 10% vanadium calcined at 800 C, and in catalysts used for 200 h. Quantitative estimations showed that most vanadium introduced into the catalyst occurs in these samples as Mg3(V04)2. In the reduced catalysts the orthovanadate phase disappears and no new phase becomes visible. The X-ray spectrum of pure magnesium orthovanadate, measured for comparison after reduction with ethylbenzene at 560 C, remains unchanged, indicating that solid Mg3(V04):2 is irreducible under the reaction conditions. The suggestion, based upon X-ray studies, that vanadium is highly dis- persed is supported by the photographs obtained in an electron microscope (Fig. 3). A comparison of pictures obtained for a freshly-prepared catalyst containing 10% vanadium, calcined at 600 and 800 C and after use, shows that the orthovanadate phase in the catalyst calcined at 600 C has the highest dispersion. The results of studies discussed thus far indicate that the active portion of the catalyst is highly-dispersed magnesium orthovanadate coordinated with the MgO surface. A further increase in vanadium content up to 14% does not result in any change in catalyst activity, and the yield of styrene is maintained at about 57%. The degree of conversion and selectivity also increase initially with increasing vanadium content, and on exceeding 8% vanadium they remain unchanged at 66 and 86%, respectively. The dependence of C02 yield on vanadium content in the catalyst is shown in Fig. 4. The amount of CO^ decreases from about 13 to 9% with an increase in vanadium content from 2 to 14%. The effect of thermal treatment on the activities of catalysts is presented in Table 3. It can be seen that on increasing the temperature of calcination over the range 600 to 800 C, the yield of styrene decreases from 58.5 to 44% while the specific surface of the catalyst decreases from the initial value of 65.5 to 40 m2 g~1. The yield of styrene per m2 of the catalyst surface increases according to the data presented in Table 3. The catalyst calcined at 600 C for 200 h has the same activity as that calcined at 700 C, and has a comparable specific surface. On the other hand, the specific surface of catalyst after 200 h in use decreases to 19 m2 g~1 and the yield of styrene increases to 1.65 W m~2. These changes result from textural changes occur- ing under varying reaction conditions. The average oxidation state of vanadium in the reduced catalysts calcu- lated on the basic of chemical analyses is 3.6 - 3.9 (Table 4). For V^Os reduced under the same conditions it is 3.25. The reducibility of the catalysts increases with increasing vanadium content. Infrared and Roman scattering spectra From measurements of IR and RS spectra of V^Os/MgO catalysts we hoped to establish the structure of the active phase and the role of the 118 w[7.] .60 40 [ / ] 15 2 4 6 8 10 f2 X %V Fig. 5. Effect of total vanadium content in the catalyst on the yield of styrene and V4'1' concentration. W = styrene yield. vanadium-oxygen bonds in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene. In Figs. 6 and 7, the IR and RS spectra of fresh and reduced catalysts as well as those ofvanadium(III), (IV) and (V) oxides are compared. Spectroscopic data obtained for VzO; and its reduction products, 'V^0^ and V203, may be compared with the results of spectral measurements for both fresh and reduced V^Os/MgO catalysts. It may be concluded from such a comparison that VzOg deposited on MgO loses its oxide nature. As a result of the chemical reaction at 400 - 600 C, a surface phase is formed which has the properties of a chemical compound. This indicates that there is no similarity between the spectra of catalysts and those of vanadium oxides mentioned above. Over the vanadium-oxygen stretching region the IR spectrum of a fresh catalyst consists of seven clearly separate bands situated at 956, 913, 870, 820, 763, 685 and 590 cnT1. The RS spectrum in this region contains six lines of the following energies: 999, 940, 868, 834, 768 and 532 cm"1. Thus, one can observe considerably enriched spectral contours for which neither the number of bands nor the energy distribution parallels that of the spectrum of V^Og. 119 Fig. 6. IR spectra of the V^O^, V;04, V^Os and V^Os/MgO catalysts (fresh and reduced); * in MgV spectrum represents negative compensation for MgO (486 cm"1 band). 120 a>0 4oo 6eo eco moo ISXi 1400 1600 16DO zoco cm"1 200 ^x> ax> saa 1 0 "Oo tioo feoo 1830 SBOO Fig. 7. Raman scattering spectra of vanadium oxides compared with that of vanadate catalysts. A change of the vanadium content in the catalyst from 2 to 14% does not affect the band distribution, but only the band intensity with respect to strong absorption associated with the carrier. The surface phase band distributions for the catalyst seemed to be similar to those of the vanadate spectra, known for many years and documented by Baran et al. [7], Griffith et al. [8], Brown and Ross [9], Weinstock et al. [10] and Schwendt and Grans [11]. In order to determine the composition of the surface layer and to assign the spectral contour to a specific structure, we have carried out 121 comparative spectroscopic studies of the magnesium vanadates MgY^Og, MgzV207 and MgyV^Os. Their IR and RS spectra are illustrated in Figs. 8 and 9, and the frequencies, relative band intensities and assignments are pre- sented in Tables 5 and 6. The spectra of fresh catalysts are very similar to those of magnesium orthovanadate. Over the stretching frequency region from 500 to 1000 cm"* these similarities are considerable, both with respect to the transition energies and their intensities. Over the FIR region the bands are distorted by MgO absorption and, therefore, this similarity becomes less pronounced. The highest energy band of the multiplet is much stronger than the diphon 230 400 BOO 600 moo Fig. 8. IR spectra of several vanadates formed in the 'V^Os/MgO binary system: Mg3(V04)2, MgaVaO,, MgV^Oa. 122 330 400 600 830 BOO WO Fig. 9. Raman scattering spectra of vanadates formed in the V^Og/MgO binary system. absorption found for magnesium orthovanadate at 962 cm~1 (Fig. 8). The origin of that transition is thus attributed to ^(V^O) vibrations of the second surface layer component. This component is most probably the system of octahedral active centres, forming, with a tetrahedral framework, a spinel-type lattice of the surface layer. Certain differences in the spectra of catalysts and orthovanadate are revealed in the Raman scattering spectra. Apart from the bands characteristic of Mgy(VO^)^ these spectra also contain new bands at 999,940 and 768 cm~1, which correspond most probably to ^(V^O), ^(V^^O) and ras(VOV) vibrations of the octahedral component in the surface layer. Our studies do not support the thesis suggested by Speranskaya [5] on the existence of the Mg3V40i3 vanadate formed from the binary 3MgO X 2Vz05 phase. The IR spectral contour of that compound (Fig. 8) indicates clearly that, in fact, we are dealing with a mixture of divanadate and meta- vanadate. Reduction of the catalyst brings about pronounced changes in its vibrational spectra and leads to the decline of the 910 - 1000 cm~1 bands. Since these bands are related to the vanadium(V)-oxygen stretching frequencies, this fact indicates that during reduction V(V) undergoes con- version to lower oxidation states. A broad absorption between 800 and 910 cm~1 contains the bands corresponding to the vanadyl bond ^(V^^O) in the square pyramid complex and to asymmetric vibrations of the vanadium(IV) and (III) VOV bridges. Diffuse reflectance spectra Diffuse reflectance spectra measured in the present work are presented in Figs. 10 and 11 and Tables 7 and 8. UV-VIS spectra of freshly-prepared catalysts exhibit considerable differences in the band intensities of the red and blue spectral regions. Absorptions over the 9000 - 22000 cm"1 range are almost 10 times weaker than those in the 22 000 - 48 000 cm~i region. These differences result from the different natures of the electron transitions which become activated in both energy regions. CT transitions of the vanadium(V) oxy-species lead to a spectral contour consisting of 3 - 5 bands whose centres of gravity occur at about 47 000, 42 000, 37 000, 30 000 and 25000 cm"1. The strongest bands, at 30000 and 37000 - 40000 cm"1, correspond to (7r)ti -> d(e) and {iT)t^ -> d(e) transitions of the tetrahedral com- ponent of the surface layer. The lower intensity bands of that region are con- nected with the second component of the surface layer possessing octahedral structure. The discussion of the electron spectra for that element may be referred to the energy diagram (Fig. 12) constructed by the method employed by Ballhausen and Gray for vanadyl complexes [12]. The bands found at 42 000 and 47 000 cm~1 are in agreement with the energy difference between the e level of oxygen and b2 level of vanadium(V). The LCT bands at 25 000 cm~1 according to So and Pope [13] correspond to the bi(7r) - h^(xy) transition. The optical spectra of the catalysts in the 11 000 - 21 000 cm"1 range are characterized by three d-d transitions of vanadium(IV). The first band, bi - e*, lies in the 12 500 - 13 400 range, the second b^ -" b? in the 15 600 - 16200 and third b;,--at in the 18500 - 21400 cm~1 range. Energies and intensities of these bands are typical of the vanadyl chromophore coordinated in the square pyramid complex structure [14]. These ions occur both in freshly-prepared catalysts and in the vanadium pentoxide used in their synthesis, where they result from structural defects, so-called deficiency oxygen holes. Some vanadyl centres occur also in vanadates, as indicated from the presence of the corresponding bands in the spectra presented in Fig. 11. The effect of catalyst lattice defects is of considerable importance, since the initial number of vanadyl centres determines catalyst activity in the transformation of ethylbenzene into styrene. The reduction process changes the spectrum of the catalyst considerably (Fig. 10). The maximum absorption of reduced catalysts occurs at 44000 cmr1 and other weaker bands occur at 41000, 35000 and 47600 cm"1. The IR absorption region (4000 - 7000 cm~1) in the spectra of precur- sors and reduced catalysts exhibits weak bands characteristic of the two- and three-phonon vibrational transitions. These bands are found in all samples at 4240, 4350, 5250, 7240 and 7330 cm-1, and also in those which were kept for long times at elevated temperatures, though in this case the 131 bands are much weaker. These bands result most probably from the aquo- and hydroxy groups occurring on the catalyst surface as products of the oxidative dehydrogenation. The spectral contour of the catalyst reduced for 5 - 6 h at the reaction temperature and also at 500 C is similar to that presented in Fig. 10. The difference consists of two additional bands, a shoulder at about 25 000 cm"' and a very clear band at about 16300 cm"1. These additional absorptions correspond most probably to the d-d transitions of the vanadium(III) ions. The electronic spectra of the octahedrally-coordinated V(III) ion should consist of three spin-allowed d-d transitions [15 -17]. These can be assigned in terms of the Q^ nomenclature as v^. ^(F) - ^g; v^. ^(F) -^ ^^(P) and VT,: ^^(F) -> ^A^. The two lowest spin-allowed y; and v^ transitions for the VOfi chromophore appear at 17 500 and 25 000 cm"1. The third spin-allowed band is expected to occur in the 30 000 - 40 000 cm"1 region and is usually obscured by CT bands [15]. These two additional absorptions found in the spectra of catalysts operating for more than 5 h indicate deep reduction in the catalysts, and the V(III) ions most probably represent the final stage of the process. Luminescence spectra The mechanism of the luminescence transitions for the tetra- oxovanadium(v) ions is attributed to the emission from the lowest excited 3^^ (ti -> 2e) state to the 'Ai ground state. In view of the small energy differ- ence between the 3^^ and ^2, it is expected that at higher temperatures the 3^ i level also plays a significant role in the luminescence process [18]. The luminescence mecha:iism described may be applied to the 'V^Os/MgO catalysts, since it is also based upon charge-transfer transitions. The ESR studies discussed above reveal the existence of two types of V02"1" ions in the catalysts, those which are isolated and homogeneously dispersed and those which are amorphous with cluster properties. Magnetic exchange between the V(IV) ions belonging to the second type leads to a small decrease of the magnetic moment due to spin-pairing between adjacent metal ions, which is a very well known phenomenon 133]. The presence of the oxygen bond facilitates exchange interactions between the V(IV) ions in the catalysts. Such interactions result not only in partial spin-pairing for catalysts rich in vanadium, but also in a dependence of the magnetic suscep- tibility on the magnetic field and in a dependence of magnetic moments on the temperature. Reaction mechanism The physicochemical studies discussed above provide various informa- tion on the structure of the surface layer and on the mechanism of the reaction under investigation. The catalyst surface layer, formed mainly by 141 the tetrahedral V04 framework, contains a certain number of embedded octahedral V(V) sites which contain an oxo-type terminal oxygen and are connected to other layer components by means of oxygen bridges. This type of structure resembles the spinel-type lattice in which octahedral poly- hedra are linked via their edges with the tetrahedral base. Oxygen vacancies of the polymeric vanadate layer form another system of active sites consisting of five-coordinated vanadyl ions with a square pyramid structure. The V^Og/MgO catalysts belong to a group of mixed valence systems, and their catalytic properties in the oxidative dehydrogenation are related to the structure of their active sites consisting of V(V) and V(IV) ions. The oxygen bridge linking these ions allows electron exchange between them and acts as an electron transmitter. Both V(V) and V(IV) cooperate closely in the oxidative dehydrogenation process. The V(III) ions are most probably the final stage of the catalytic process, and result from the deficit in the reoxidative atmosphere, The mechanism of the reaction under investigation may be explained on the basis of a highly dynamic model of the working catalyst. Mechanism of the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene (via the o-complex) on the V^Os/MgO catalyst. The first mechanism consists of the formation of an ethylbenzene complex with the active catalyst site, as occurs with Mo03/MgO catalysts [I], and is illustrated in Fig. 17. On the other hand, the second mechanism proceeds through the formation of the o-complex; the diagram of that reaction is presented in Fig. 18. coredata.dc:description: A mechanism of oxidative dehydrogenation converting ethylbenzene to styrene on V2O5/MgO catalysts is suggested. The nature and structure of the VVVIV active centres is discussed on the basis of the physicochemical (radiographic, thermogravimetric, electron microscopic, IR, RS, UV, VIS, ESR, luminescence and magnetic) properties. The VVVIV/VIII redox system linked by oxygen bridges was shown to play an important role in the catalytic process.
coredata.dc:title: Structure of the active layer and catalytic mechanism of the V2O5/MgO catalysts in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene
